adjacent-sibling-combinators.summary: The adjacent sibling combinator (+) separates two selectors and matches the second element only if it immediately follows the first element, and both are children of the same parent element.

notes: Internet Explorer 7 doesn't update the style correctly when an element is dynamically placed before an element that matched the selector.
In Internet Explorer 8, if an element is inserted dynamically by clicking on a link the first-child style isn't applied until the link loses focus.

adjacent-sibling-combinators.title: Adjacent sibling combinator

attribute-selectors.summary: The CSS attribute selector matches elements based on the presence or value of a given attribute.
attribute-selectors.title: Attribute selectors

checked.summary: The :checked CSS pseudo-class selector represents any radio (input type="radio"), checkbox (input type="checkbox"), or option (option in a select) element that is checked or toggled to an on state.
checked.title: :checked

child-combinators.summary: The child combinator () is placed between two CSS selectors. It matches only those elements matched by the second selector that are the children of elements matched by the first.
child-combinators.title: Child combinator

class-html.summary: The CSS class selector matches elements based on the contents of their class attribute.
class-html.title: Class selectors

descendant-combinators.summary: The descendant combinator — typically represented by a single space ( ) character — combines two selectors such that elements matched by the second selector are selected if they have an ancestor element matching the first selector. Selectors that utilize a descendant combinator are called descendant selectors.

notes: >>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.
>>> is aliased to this selector since its use as the 'shadow-piercing descendant combinator' was deprecated.

descendant-combinators.title: Descendant combinator

empty-pseudo.summary: The :empty CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has no children. Children can be either element nodes or text (including whitespace). Comments or processing instructions do not affect whether an element is considered empty.
empty-pseudo.title: :empty

enableddisabled.summary: The :disabled CSS pseudo-class represents any disabled element. An element is disabled if it can't be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has an enabled state, in which it can be activated or accept focus.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer does not recognize :disabled on the <fieldset> element.

enableddisabled.title: :disabled

enableddisabled.summary: The :enabled CSS pseudo-class represents any enabled element. An element is enabled if it can be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has a disabled state, in which it can't be activated or accept focus.
enableddisabled.title: :enabled

first-child-pseudo.summary: The :first-child CSS pseudo-class represents the first element among a group of sibling elements.

notes: Internet Explorer 7 doesn't update :first-child styles when elements are added dynamically.
In Internet Explorer 8, if an element is inserted dynamically by clicking on a link, then the :first-child style isn't applied until the link loses focus.

first-child-pseudo.title: :first-child

first-letter.summary: The ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first letter of the first line of a block-level element, but only when not preceded by other content (such as images or inline tables).
first-letter.title: ::first-letter (:first-letter)

first-line.summary: The ::first-line CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first line of a block-level element.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

opera.notes: From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

safari.notes: The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.
The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.

first-line.title: ::first-line (:first-line)

first-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :first-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the first element of its type among a group of sibling elements.
first-of-type-pseudo.title: :first-of-type

gen-content.summary: In CSS, ::after creates a pseudo-element that is the last child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property.

notes: Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::after pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.
Before Firefox 3.5, only the CSS level 2 behavior of :after was supported, which disallowed position, float, list-style-* and some display properties.

gen-content.title: ::after (:after)

gen-content.summary: In CSS, ::before creates a pseudo-element that is the first child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property.

notes: Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::before pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.
Before Firefox 3.5, only the CSS level 2 behavior of :before was supported, which disallowed position, float, list-style-* and some display properties.

gen-content.title: ::before (:before)

general-sibling-combinators.summary: The general sibling combinator (~) separates two selectors and matches the second element only if it follows the first element (though not necessarily immediately), and both are children of the same parent element.
general-sibling-combinators.title: General sibling combinator

id-selectors.summary: The CSS ID selector matches an element based on the value of its id attribute. In order for the element to be selected, its ID attribute must match exactly the value given in the selector.
id-selectors.title: ID selectors

lang-pseudo.summary: The :lang() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the language they are determined to be in.
lang-pseudo.title: :lang()

last-child.summary: The :last-child CSS pseudo-class represents the last element among a group of sibling elements.
last-child.title: :last-child

last-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :last-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the last element of its type among a group of sibling elements.
last-of-type-pseudo.title: :last-of-type

link.summary: The :link CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has not yet been visited. It matches every unvisited a, area, or link element that has an href attribute.
link.title: :link

link.summary: The :visited CSS pseudo-class represents links that the user has already visited. For privacy reasons, the styles that can be modified using this selector are very limited.
link.title: :visited

negation.summary: The :not() CSS pseudo-class represents elements that do not match a list of selectors. Since it prevents specific items from being selected, it is known as the negation pseudo-class.
negation.title: :not()

nth-child-pseudo.summary: The :nth-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position in a group of siblings.

opera.notes: Before Opera 15, Opera does not handle dynamically inserted elements for :nth-child().

opera_android.notes: Before Opera 15, Opera does not handle dynamically inserted elements for :nth-child().

nth-child-pseudo.title: :nth-child()

nth-last-child-pseudo.summary: The :nth-last-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.
nth-last-child-pseudo.title: :nth-last-child()

nth-last-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :nth-last-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.
nth-last-of-type-pseudo.title: :nth-last-of-type()

nth-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :nth-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements of a given type, based on their position among a group of siblings.
nth-of-type-pseudo.title: :nth-of-type()

only-child-pseudo.summary: The :only-child CSS pseudo-class represents an element without any siblings. This is the same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.
only-child-pseudo.title: :only-child

only-of-type-pseudo.summary: The :only-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has no siblings of the same type.
only-of-type-pseudo.title: :only-of-type

root-pseudo.summary: The :root CSS  pseudo-class matches the root element of a tree representing the document. In HTML, :root represents the html element and is identical to the selector html, except that its specificity is higher.
root-pseudo.title: :root

target-pseudo.summary: The :target CSS pseudo-class represents a unique element (the target element) with an id matching the URL's fragment.
target-pseudo.title: :target

the-user-action-pseudo-classes-hover-act.summary: The :focus CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a form input) that has received focus. It is generally triggered when the user clicks or taps on an element or selects it with the keyboard's "tab" key.
the-user-action-pseudo-classes-hover-act.title: :focus

the-user-action-pseudo-classes-hover-act.summary: The :hover CSS pseudo-class matches when the user interacts with an element with a pointing device, but does not necessarily activate it. It is generally triggered when the user hovers over an element with the cursor (mouse pointer).

safari_ios.notes: As of Safari for iOS 7.1.2, tapping a clickable element causes the element to enter the :hover state. The element will remain in the :hover state until a different element has entered the :hover state.

the-user-action-pseudo-classes-hover-act.title: :hover

type-selectors.summary: The CSS type selector matches elements by node name. In other words, it selects all elements of the given type within a document.
type-selectors.title: Type selectors

universal-selector.summary: The CSS universal selector (*) matches elements of any type.
universal-selector.title: Universal selectors

useraction-pseudos.summary: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user.
useraction-pseudos.title: :active
